linesOfText.text: Sophie didn’t really understand words
when she was a small baby
but already, she knew how
to listen to her heart.
It’s what made her smile
when she saw her parents.
And when she was only
a few months older
Sophie could tell when someone
was happy or sad.
She would immediately feel the same way.
As she got even older, Sophie began to
learn how to use words to express herself,
and how to use her hands to play.
She would often use both
to get what she wanted.
But it was her hands that seemed
to serve her most.
She used her hands to paint, to play cards and to turn the pages of her books.
She could spend hours clapping her hands against other little hands
to the tune of a rhyming game or song. Clap – Clap – Clap. “Music to my ears!” she would say.
Since her hands were such a focus, she would often draw even more attention to them
by painting bright and glittery colours on her nails.
“Today, I’m going to paint stars on them,” she announced proudly.
Sophie’s hands were taking on more and more importance.
On this sunny but chilly spring day, Sophie used her hands to help her mommy
and little sister water the flowers outside in the garden.
All three were taking turns with the hose to give the thirsty flowers
lots of water to help them grow.
“I’ll water the roses!” Sophie said cheerfully.
Sophie loved being with her family.
"My turn!” Sophie’s little sister, Anne, said excitedly as she grabbed the hose.
It was all fun until they got to the last few flowers.
That’s when Sophie started to get bored.
“This is taking too long,” she complained.
“I want more turns with the hose.”
Turning away from her mother and sister, who continued to water the flowers in turn,
Sophie decided to make up her own fun.
She began to imagine the backyard changing right in front of her eyes.
The grass slowly began to rise all around her, and wild animals could be heard in the distance.
“A jungle!” she cried in excitement.
“I’ll pretend I’m in a jungle!”
Sophie watched as flowers turned
into little monkeys bouncing off the stones.
Leaves turned into birds of all colours.
Some of the trees grew into giant giraffes
with their heads peeking through the clouds.
And in the middle of all this, Sophie stood as the proud and fearless explorer!
“Now, this is going to be fun!” she said.
Dressed in an impressive safari outfit,
Sophie bravely roamed the green and lush jungle in search of a big adventure.
It did not take long before she found it.
As she stared ahead, a giant lion with a curly mane of blond hair was coming straight for her!
“GRRRR,” it roared before charging at her.
Sophie dropped onto the hard ground and grabbed the weapon that was waiting there.
Looking determined, she pointed it on the lion.
“I’ve got you now!” she told the approaching animal.
But something inside her made Sophie pause.
She knew exactly who was coming towards her.
Ignoring that heavy feeling,
Sophie let her hands take over and splashed poor
little Anne with a huge gush of water.
“Sophie!”
Her mother’s loud complaint woke Sophie from her daydream
and she was faced with her little sister crying loudly.
Two-year-old Anne’s eyes were wide and confused.
She did not know why she had been sprayed with a cold burst of water.
“Sophie!” her mother shouted again. “Why would you do that?”
Sophie looked at her little sister in tears, and her own eyes began to water.
She looked back at her mother.
She thought about it for only a minute.
She wanted to say that it was all a mistake
but she knew that was a lie.
So instead, she said what she felt:
“I just didn’t listen to my heart.”
“My mouth doesn’t always tell the truth,” she admitted.
"But my heart never lies. My heart was telling me not to do it, but my hands wouldn’t listen!”
Sophie then turned to her little sister. “I'm sorry Annie,” she said.
Sophie wrapped her hands around her sister and the two shared a big, warm hug.
The End.
